subs.text: March 30

@RLLongyear @boltyboy @JohnNosta @drgautamgulati @RasuShrestha @DrShlain @StephanieKuku @jayparkinson @chrissyfarr @nikillinit @healthythinker @VentureValkyrie @RLLongyear - It's two. @boltyboy is correct. subs.text: @HITPrivacy @HHSGov @ONC_HealthIT I am not as fiercely opinionated as you, @HITPrivacy (I'll blame your legal training!) -  I concur that there were (are) misdeeds and we need a framework that is less reactive and more proactive going forward.  Predictably, I have some ideas about how this would work. :-)
subs.rawText: @HITPrivacy @HHSGov @ONC_HealthIT I am not as fiercely opinionated as you, @HITPrivacy (I'll blame your legal training!) -  I concur that there were (are) misdeeds and we need a framework that is less reactive and more proactive going forward.  Predictably, I have some ideas about how this would work. :-)

subs.text:
@lisabari Well .. I'd not go so far as "deeply flawed"  

The program is:

a) Under-funded (insufficient team to do active surveillance)

b) Difficult to evolve (regulations take too long to allow for an agile program)

 Balancing  burden to the market and safety is the key challenge

subs.text:
Context/explanation:

Health IT in the US is certified to a set of criteria.  
The criteria are explicit and are there to protect purchasers and the people (all of us) served by the purchasers.
subs.rawText:
Context/explanation:

Health IT in the US is certified to a set of criteria.  
The criteria are explicit and are there to protect purchasers and the people (all of us) served by the purchasers.

subs.text:
The most important part of this is safety.  

Itâ€™s like a car:  you buy a car and it has tires, headlights and other components that meet certification standards.  

Health IT systems are the same.  If they donâ€™t send an Rx to the pharmacy properly - it could kill you.

subs.text: @SavageLucia @claudiawilliams Learned long ago by the SUD providers: we can't help an addict until they recognize that they are an addict and they SEEK our help.  Alas, health systems = #FFSAddicts.  Therefore - nothing changes here.  No need to try.

subs.text: Once again - the evidence says "no" but (too often) the physicians still say "yes." Why? a) It's easier b) CAHPS and the human need to be liked c) fee-for-service ==> office visit ==> need to leave the visit with something (an Rx) [link]
subs.rawText: Once again - the evidence says "no" but (too often) the physicians still say "yes."    Why?  a) It's easier   b) CAHPS and the human need to be liked  c) fee-for-service ==> office visit ==> need to leave the visit with something (an Rx) https://t.co/aq9623SBWW

subs.text: March 2

@sacjai Friendly grep -rl : "healthcare" ==> health care (two words emphasizes that health < = > care) ... and "system" ==> "bowl of spaghetti." Systems are intentionally designed. What we have is not - I therefore prefer not to be so generous as my kinder friend, @sacjai. [link]
subs.rawText: @sacjai Friendly grep -rl :  "healthcare" ==> health care (two words emphasizes that health < = > care) ... and "system" ==> "bowl of spaghetti."   Systems are intentionally designed.  What we have is not -  I therefore prefer not to be so generous as my kinder friend, @sacjai. https://t.co/xkOcRsmBWT

subs.text: March 1

@HealthIT_Policy Cousin Steve, it kinda feels like y'all posted the headline and then .. "continued on page 7" but the newspaper ends on page 6!  I'll quote my 8th grade English Teacher:  "so what?"  What's the lesson here?  Complaints < > findings.  What were the findings? Consequences?
